results.title: Rhythm (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson. Explores rhythm as a fundamental part of the language of motion pictures and its integral role in film making. Addresses: 1. Rhythm does not depend on cutting 2. Changes of shot do not necessarily have any special rhythmic effect 3. Music can impose its own rhythm 4. Music and images can work together. No other credits available.

results.title: The War of words Down Under (TEFC)
results.brief_description: This program looks at the work of BUGAUP and other antismoking campaigns. It discusses the responsibility of the media, tobacco companies and government to public health.

results.title: Loyal tubthumper: Minnie Appleby
results.brief_description: This program is an account of the life of Minnie Appleby (nee Birch) who was born in 1900 and died in 1982. Minnie Appleby’s life story echoes the development of women through this century - she was a suffragette, political speaker, communist activist, housewife, mother, working woman and, later in life, women’s liberationist.

results.title: Red Matildas
results.creator_credit: Sharon Connolly, Trevor Graham and Yarra Bank Films
results.brief_description: Through the lives of three women, Audrey Blake, May Pennefather and Joan Goodwin, “Red Matildas” explores the social and political conditions in Australia during the Great Depression - conditions of massive unemployment, widespread malnutrition and growing militarism at home and abroad, that provoked many people to political activity. May Pennefather served 12-18 months in the Spanish Civil War. Cinematographer: Laurie McInnes

results.title: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington's puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
1. “Paddington in the hot seat”. Paddington has an audience ticket for the Quiz Show “Sage of Britain”. He gets lost in the studio complex and finds himself “on camera” where he is interviewed by Lionel Parr. He disputes the scoring and provides his opinion on proposed changes to British Television. The viewers jam the switchboard and Paddington is announced “Sage of Britain”. - 2. “Paddington’s puzzle”. Paddington makes a jigsaw puzzle as a present for Mr Gruber from a “priceless” old painting discarded by Mr Curry, some plywood and glue. - 3. “Paddington takes a cut”. Paddington reads “Clippings from my Hedgerow” and dreams he is pruning Mr Currys’ shrub into a peacock shape. Disaster strikes when he snips it leg off! However, awakes before discovery by Mr Curry!
results.title_for_label: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington’s puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington

results.title: Julie Julie
results.brief_description: Julie was sick of living in Broken Hill, so she bought a motorbike and left to ride around Australia. The film shows part of her journey and illustrates the sense of freedom and independence of young people breaking loose.
results.description: Julie was sick of living in Broken Hill, so she bought a motorbike and left to ride around Australia. The film shows part of her journey and illustrates the sense of freedom and independence of young people breaking loose.

results.title: Signatures of the Soul
results.brief_description: Counter-cultural icon Peter Fonda takes us on a comprehensive journey through the world of tattooing. From early tribal origins and eastern influences, right through to adoption in the mainstream and gradual acceptance as an art form, tattooing has been elevated to both art and an intense form of self-expression.
